snippet: The Supreme Court agreed to hear a challenge to the part of the act that requires some states with a history of discrimination in voting to get federal approval before making any changes to the way they hold elections.
abstract: Supreme Court announces that it will take a fresh look at the Voting Rights Act of 1965, signature legacy of the civil rights movement that covers a broad range of protections including a requirement that some state and local governments, mainly in the South, obtain federal permission before changing voting rules; court has signaled that the law may no longer be necessary, decision that could have a powerful impact on how elections are conducted.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed to hear a challenge to the part of the act that requires some states with a history of discrimination in voting to get federal approval before making any changes to the way they hold elections.

headline.seo: Supreme Court to Revisit Voting Rights Act
headline.main: Justices to Revisit Voting Act in View of a Changing South
headline.print_headline: Justices to Revisit Voting Act In View of a Changing South
